Dissociative symptoms of detachment from one's body or the world around them
duration: Symptoms usually begin within the first 3 months after the trauma.
description: A mental health condition triggered by a terrifying event—either experiencing it or witnessing it.

related_diagnoses.Acute Stress Disorder: Similar to PTSD but symptoms persist less than a month after the trauma.
related_diagnoses.Anxiety disorders: Common comorbidities include panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, etc.

duration: restricted to a duration of 3 days to 1 month following exposure to the traumatic event (acute stress disorder)
description: A mental health condition triggered by a terrifying event—either experiencing it or witnessing it.

related_diagnoses.adjustment disorders: when the response to a stressor that meets PTSD Criterion A does not meet all other PTSD criteria
related_diagnoses.other posttraumatic disorders and condit: if the symptom response pattern to the extreme stressor meets criteria for another mental disorder
related_diagnoses.major depressive disorder: may or may not be preceded by a traumatic event and should be diagnosed if other PTSD symptoms are absent.
related_diagnoses.personality disorders: interpersonal difficulties that had their onset, or were greatly exacerbated, after exposure to a traumatic event may be an indication of PTSD
related_diagnoses.dissociative disorders: When full PTSD criteria are also met, however, the PTSD "with dissociative symptoms" subtype should be considered.

symptoms: Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories of the traumatic event(s)
Recurrent distressing dreams in which the content and/or affect of the dream are related to the event(s)
Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring
Persistent inability to experience positive emotions
Altered sense of the reality of one’s surroundings or oneself
Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event(s)
Efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s)
duration: Symptoms typically begin immediately after the trauma, but persistence for at least 3 days and up to a month is needed to meet disorder criteria.
description: Essential feature is the development of characteristic symptoms lasting from 3 days to 1 month following exposure to one or more traumatic events.

related_diagnoses.Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder: Can develop if symptoms persist beyond 1 month
related_diagnoses.Adjustment Disorder: May result from stressful events that lack severity and trauma compared to Acute Stress Disorder stressors

symptoms: Recurrent and intrusive recollections of the event
Intense psychological distress or physiological reactivity upon exposure to triggering events
Persistent inability to feel positive emotions
Avoidance of discussing or engaging in activities related to the traumatic experience
Sleep disturbances, including nightmares and general elevated arousal
Quick temper and aggressive behavior with little provocation
Concentration difficulties, including memory lapses and trouble focusing
Reactive startle response or jumpiness to sudden sounds or movements
Chaotic or impulsive behavior like reckless driving, making irrational decisions, or gambling excessively
Separation anxiety in children seeking excessive attention from caregivers
Postconcussive symptoms like headaches, dizziness, irritability, and concentration deficits
duration: Lasts up to 1 month after trauma exposure.
description: A mental health condition resulting from experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event.

related_diagnoses.Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD): May progress into PTSD if persists beyond 1 month.

symptoms: play referring directly or symbolically to the trauma
avoidance of reminders of the trauma
preoccupation with reminders of the trauma
fearful reactions at the time of exposure or during reexperiencing
duration: up to 1 month after trauma exposure
description: Transient stress response
Intrusive distressing memories
Avoidance

related_diagnoses.Adjustment disorder: Response to a less severe stressor.

symptoms: marked distress out of proportion to the stressor
significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning

description: essential feature - emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: if symptoms meet criteria for MDD instead of adjustment disorder
related_diagnoses.Posttraumatic stress disorder and acute: distinguished based on timing and symptom profile

diagnosis: Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder
description: Applies to presentations with trauma- and stressor-related disorder symptoms without meeting full criteria for any specific disorder.

related_diagnoses.Adjustment-like disorders: Prolonged duration (>6 months) without prolonged stressor.

related_diagnoses.Other cultural syndromes: See Glossary of Cultural Concepts of Distress.

symptoms: Sudden alterations or discontinuities in sense of self and sense of agency

Non-epileptic seizures and other conversion symptoms
Depersonalization observership of one's own speech and actions
Perceptions of multiple independent thought streams
Strong emotions, impulses, and behaviors emerging without a sense of personal ownership or control
Attitudes, outlooks, and personal preferences shifting abruptly
Feeling that one's body feels different (e.g., like a small child)
Amnesia regarding everyday events, personal life events, and well-learned skills
Discovery of unexplained objects, writings, or drawings created by oneself

related_diagnoses.Depression: Often co-occurs with dissociative identity disorder.

symptoms: amnesia for some aspects of trauma
intrusion by dissociated identity states into the individual's sense of self and agency
infrequent, full-blown changes among different identity states
visual, tactile, olfactory, gustatory, and somatic hallucinations
depressive symptoms with persecutory and derogatory internal voices
chaotic identity change and acute intrusions disrupting thought processes
description: A mental disorder characterized by the presence of two or more distinct personality states.

related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Depression in individuals with DID may not fully meet criteria for MDD.
related_diagnoses.Bipolar Disorders: Rapid mood shifts in DID are due to subjective shifts in mood across dissociative states.
related_diagnoses.Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: Some traumatized individuals have both PTSD and DID. It is crucial to distinguish between them based on specific dissociative symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Psychotic Disorders: Symptoms like hallucination and disorganized thinking may be confused with psychosis but are caused by alter personalities in DID.

symptoms: Inability to recall important autobiographical information

Generalized amnesia for identity and life history
Mild traumatic brain injury preceding amnesia

related_diagnoses.Somatic Symptom Disorder: Often seen together with dissociative amnesia.
related_diagnoses.Major or Mild Neurocognitive Disorder: Not better explained by these conditions.

symptoms: Difficulty understanding questions about amnesia (in children)
Impairment in all aspects of functioning (chronic generalized dissociative amnesia)
duration: Can range from minutes to decades
description: A condition characterized by inability to recall important personal information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature.

related_diagnoses.Dissociative Identity Disorder: May report similar symptoms like depersonalization and auto-hypnotic symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: Some individuals with PTSD cannot recall part or all of a specific traumatic event.
related_diagnoses.Neurocognitive Disorders: Distinguishable by embedding memory loss in cognitive, linguistic, affective, attentional, and behavioral disturbances.

symptoms: Experiences of unreality or detachment with respect to one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions

duration: Persistent or recurrent episodes
description: Feelings of unreality or detachment from oneself or surroundings.
Impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Not better explained by...

symptoms: cognitive disconnection schemata reflecting defectiveness and emotional inhibition
themes of abuse, neglect, and deprivation

subjective difficulty in focusing and retaining information
general sense of disconnectedness from life
obsessions about subjective experience or developing rituals checking on the status of symptoms
altered sense of self and agency
alterations of identity or episodes of possession without dissociative amnesia
identity disturbance due to prolonged and intense coercive persuasion
description: A psychological state marked by feelings of detachment from oneself or one's surroundings.

related_diagnoses.Dissociative Identity Disorder: Should not be diagnosed when symptoms occur within the context of this disorder.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Excludes psychosis unless accompanied by intact reality testing regarding depersonalization/derealization symptoms.

profound unresponsiveness or insensitivity to environmental stimuli

individuals with excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms or associated health concerns
authentic suffering despite non-serious medical explanation for symptoms
high level of worry about illness and tendency to attribute normal bodily sensations to physical illness

frequent requests for medical help and consultation with multiple doctors for the same symptoms
unresponsiveness to medical interventions and unusual sensitivity to medication side effects
focus on somatic symptoms leading to presentation to general medical health services instead of mental health services

description: condition characterized by excessive thoughts, feelings, and behaviors regarding somatic symptoms (bodily symptoms)

related_diagnoses.Conversion Disorder (Functional Neurolog: differentiates through focusing on loss of function versus distress caused by specific symptoms

Easily alarmed about personal health status

loss of awareness with amnesia for the attack

involves a failure to explain symptoms by a known medical or neurological disorder.

related_diagnoses.Eating disorders: Similarities in persistence and concealment of behavior

related_diagnoses.Conduct Disorder: May be present when incontinence is clearly deliberate.

related_diagnoses.Histrionic Personality Disorder: Share impulsiveness, superficiality, excitement-seeking, recklessness, seductiveness, and manipulativeness; however, histrionic PD is characterized by exaggeration in emotions and doesn't typically involve antisocial behavior.
related_diagnoses.Borderline Personality Disorder: Both manipulate to gain nurturance; however, those with antisocial PD are more aggressive and less emotionally unstable.
related_diagnoses.Paranoid Personality Disorder: May exhibit antisocial behavior motivated by revenge instead of personal gain or exploitation.
